data.title: Mouse position unknown until mouse moved
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
GoDot v2.1.2

**Issue description:**
If the mouse didn't move the system doesn't know the position, even after a button was clicked. I am not sure about the behavior on touchscreen, have to test it yet.
related to https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/1212

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create a 2D node
- add `func _input(event):
	if event.type == InputEvent.MOUSE_BUTTON:
		print(get_global_mouse_pos())`
- launch application, don't move the cursor and click mouse button

**Link to minimal example project:**
[bug-mouse-move.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/868955/bug-mouse-move.zip)
launch the app, don't move the mouse and click any button, you will see that global position remains 0,0

data.title: Proposal for a better "start-up screen" (aka Project Manager)
data.body:
This sprouted a bit from the discussion about #8134. A better welcome screen could provide

- list of all created/imported projects
- a better "new project" screen, where we could provide options for a few basic templates (2d, 3d, GUI application, etc). This also because @reduz mentioned that in Godot 3, 3d games should have a default skybox.
- temples/asset lib (maybe a better name could be found? online content?)
- a quick-start help screen with links to the main docs, Q&A, video channels, etc
- quick access to editor settings (language, hidpi, control scheme, etc)

I did a very quick change in the layout of the project manager screen to include a few of these changes
![vkossza](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1642015/24308913/c4035e92-10c1-11e7-86e6-70487e8db258.png)

notice that I also added a "automatically start this project on start". I found this option quite useful. When you are working on a serious project, you dont really start Godot for anything else, so its good to just jump right-in :)

Would be great to hear more options on this and get the discussion started!

data.title: Add a "first start" dialog to the editor to improve user experience
data.body:
Software like [IntelliJ](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/2017.1/running-intellij-idea-ultimate-for-the-first-time.html) features a "first start" dialog where the user can choose essential settings such as language, editor layout, control scheme, and more.

It was also suggested that the user can also change the DPI mode and font size from there (in case automatic detection failed or is not suited to the display).

If the user changes at least one setting that requires an editor restart there, the user should be prompted to restart the editor (with a button, for example).

data.title: Input: Refactor JOY_* constants.
data.body:
**Breaking change**

Removed the `JOY_SNES_*` and `JOY_SEGA_*` constants. Imho there's no reason for a modern game engine to provide button aliases for decades-old hardware.
Also renamed `JOY_ANALOG_{0,1}_{X,Y}` to `JOY_ANALOG_{L,R}{X,Y}` and removed `JOY_ANALOG_2_*`.

data.title: Use atan2 rather than acos in Vector3.angle_to.
data.body: Fixes #8111.

data.title: Flickering when moving past sprites with camera zoomed in
data.body:
Godot v 2.1.2. x64 Linux Kubuntu 16.10

When using camera zoom in 2D and moving character all static sprites start to flicker. 

Example project: [Bad Zoom.tar.gz](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/867207/Bad.Zoom.tar.gz)

data.title: Cache DynamicFont resource for Android
data.body:
same as #7852 but for master.
Tested on Nexus 6p.

data.title: {Feature Request]  Overlapping Tabs
data.body:
Hi,
Perhaps add an option to increase the width of Tabs, so the selected Tab overlaps the others? Overlapping tabs is a cool and not uncommon visual effect.

Here's some pictures of a game that uses them. Follow the yellow arrow in the screenshots.
http://tinypic.com/view.php?pic=e6o9bb&s=9
http://tinypic.com/view.php?pic=30t2om1&s=9

data.title: Fix wrong app name for Android export
data.body: It shows version name like "1.0" instead of package/name or project name.

data.title: Changing default val of exported variable in script should change default val of this variable in already instanced nodes
data.body:
_**bugsquad edit**:_
Tested on 2.1.2, and 2.0. and 1.1 

Symptoms of this issue are visible on this gif:
![exportdefaultvaltest](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/24290611/df8f3474-1085-11e7-80e9-b56049db2ae8.gif)

Reproduction steps:
1. Create new script
2. Attach it to a node
3. Create new exported variable _integerVariable_ in the script with default value = 5
4. Save the script, look at the inspector _integerVariable_ will have correct value of 5
5. Do NOT change exported variable in inspector.
6. Change default value inside the script.
7. Value in inspector is not updated.  

sidenote: after doing some test on older Godot **I don't know if this is a bug** or design decision. As far as I remember to have that kind of 'automatic update' behavior you always needed to create subscene in a separate file and update variables in inspector of this subscene.

------------------------------


Currently (as of 2.1.2), attempting to change the default value (in the code editor) of an exported variable leaves every instance (Including the original instance, which has thrown me off several times when editing) with it's previous default value. 

I can understand the reason for this (ensuring the variables of previously edited instances are not overwritten) but I would prefer if instead of this implementation, you could just set an exported variable as "Changed" (with the revert icon appearing) on an instance to ensure it isn't overwritten and overwrite every instance with an "Unchanged" value whenever the default value is changed

data.body:
Would be nice to have a drag and drop feature for the Input keys like Autoload has.

data.title: Clear all children of a node
data.body:
I am looking for something like `node.clear()` in gd.

Can we add this to node?

data.title: [3.0] - Ideas
data.body:
Please, add some AI facility such as: neural networks, behaviour trees. These should not be full implementations, but allow these to be implemented in scripting with ease.
Also, I don't know if terrains are still used today, but it would be cool to see them in.
Finally, physics should be enhanced with fluids and soft bodies.

Please, share your toughts.

data.title: Make inline blocks in GDScript more (or less) pythonic
data.body:
Fixes #8001

From https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/8001#issuecomment-288686466 on it: (Quoting just in case)
> So, testing with python3, the following are allowed:
> ```py3
> if 1: print(1)
> if 1:
>   print(1)
> for i in (0,1,2): print(1)
> ```
> While the following are not:
> ```py3
> if 1: print(1)
>   print(2)
> for i in (0,1,2): if 1: print(1)
> for i in (0,1,2): if 1:
>   print(1)
> ```
> 
> Currently, in GDScript, all of the first group are allowed, in addition to:
> ```gdscript
> if 1: print(1)
>   print(2)
> for i in [0,1,2]: if 1: print(1)
> ```

With this PR, GDScript now supports the following:
```gdscript
for i in (0,1,2): if 1:
  print(1)
for i in (0,1,2): if 1: print(1)
```
But, it also drop the support for the following:
```gdscript
if 1: print(1)
  print(2)
```

data.title: Explicitly documented that Transform.basis is not necessarily an orth…
data.body:
…ogonal matrix.

Also added a check that in axis-angle rotations, axis is a normalized vector, and modified the docs accordingly.

Fixes #8113.

data.title: Can apply CanvasItemMaterial to 3D Nodes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
All - Godot master (a69e449)

**Issue description:**
In the inspector, for any `GeometryInstance` derived node, you can falsely set a `CanvasItemMaterial` as the `material_override` property. Doing so will crash the game at runtime, the editor keeps working.


**Steps to reproduce:**
- Add a `TestCube` to a scene.
- In the inspector, click on the `Material Override` property. You can choose to create a new `CanvasItemMaterial`

data.title: SSAO doesn't apply under a plane
data.body:
Tested on Godot 3.0 c37fad650f92845a6f59740fea2fea1b46f56db1
Windows 10 64 bits

~~I'm trying to get SSAO working, but I can't get any result so far. The best I could get were a few rare noisy dots on a model, but on trivial stuff like cubes and planes I get nothing. Not sure if it's badly configured, but so far I didn't find a way to make it work...~~ 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/24228408/49aa1d64-0f74-11e7-9add-027d6c925b25.png)

EDIT: I actually forgot to set the light affect parameter, so SSAO is actually visible now. However there is a "glitch", some parts are unexpectingly not darkened, and the viewport border is darkened:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/24267488/bcb10778-100a-11e7-9c3c-1c371a7f0e41.png)

While they are correct in the non-blurred buffer:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/24267526/d7130990-100a-11e7-8ba8-482712abac78.png)

data.title: Screen-space reflections issues
data.body:
Tested on Godot 3.0 master
Windows 10 64 bits, nVidia GeForce 940M

I tested screen-space reflections on a mesh with a metalness of 0.5, but they don't look good. I don't know what to do to fix them, I dabbled a little in the options of WorldEnvironment but none of the settings gave a good-looking result.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/24227258/3a6b2d96-0f6c-11e7-8758-01ac69dcac36.png)

Setting `accel` to zero and increasing the number of iterations to 256 seemed to improve a bit, but it still looks jagged and lag is noticeable:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/24227574/63f5c0fc-0f6e-11e7-9849-287f6911e8ab.png)

Trying on a flat plane looks ok, but the sky is not reflected (solid blue color). Also there are some edge-clamp artefacts, very noticeable when the camera is moving (not sure if that is fixable given it's "screen space"... Maybe fallback on a static cubemap, or fade to sky? I read some interesting techniques here http://www.gamasutra.com/blogs/BartlomiejWronski/20140129/209609/The_future_of_screenspace_reflections.php, I guess ReflectionProbes are designed for this but I couldn't get a difference with them)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/24227711/8532b7f6-0f6f-11e7-85c3-03518deb1bd1.png)
I was able to set a metalness of 2, which gave a more contrasted look. However it gets clamped to 1 so I guess it was not really allowed?
Also transparency seems to be incompatible with reflections, they disappear as soon as "transparency" is checked in the material.
Is there a way to make reflections "blurry"? I tried roughness but it has no effect.

Here is a video of the water plane: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NbkvuQWgnkg&feature=youtu.be

Another one of a demo I'm making, not focused on reflections but still noticeable artefacts https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r-doDosEA3E

The project: 
[ScreenSpaceReflections.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/863419/ScreenSpaceReflections.zip)

data.title: Gizmos lose their colors
data.body:
Tested on Godot 3.0 master c37fad650f92845a6f59740fea2fea1b46f56db1
Windows 10 64 bits 

Sometimes gizmos get coloured in very transparent black, making it hard to tell which axis is which. I don't know yet how it happened but that was quick, after I started adding a few meshes to a scene and creating materials. Closing the scene and reopening doesn't fix it. It also affects the grid.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/24227464/84f80022-0f6d-11e7-9201-76658d6b6e48.png)

data.title: Changing the main scene of a project sets the current scene as modified
data.body:
Tested on Godot 3.0 c37fad650f92845a6f59740fea2fea1b46f56db1
Windows 10 64 bits

Minor bug: save the current scene, then go to Project Settings, change the main scene (even when choosing the same one), close Project Settings. Notice the current scene is now marked as modified (*).
I didn't expect that because the setting I changed doesn't modify the scene, it only modifies godot.cfg.

data.title: Drag and drop doesn't work in the 3D editor
data.body:
Tested on Godot 3.0 master c37fad650f92845a6f59740fea2fea1b46f56db1
Windows 10 64 bits

I cannot drag a .obj mesh on a MeshInstance node. I can't do it either on the mesh property.

data.title: Improved 2D snapping behavior
data.body:
Make snapping affect nodes created by drag & drop
Make snapping for a single Node2D refer to its pivot
Refactor duplicate drag setup code
Replace one occurrence of the old `set_pos()` by `set_position()`

data.title: Improved 2D snapping behavior (2.1)
data.body:
Make snapping affect nodes created by drag & drop
Make snapping for a single Node2D refer to its pivot
Refactor duplicate drag setup code

data.title: [3.0] Basis gets broken when rotating a Camera
data.body:
Tested on Godot 3.0 master
Windows 10 64 bits

I tested my 3D debug camera, and after attempting to fix it for the new rotation convention, I've come to a point where it works, but shortly breaks completely by logging an endless stream of errors in the console.

This is the code:

```gdscript
set_rotation(Vector3(0, deg2rad(_yaw), 0))
rotate(get_transform().basis.x, -deg2rad(_pitch)) # rotate around local axis
```

And the errors:


Repro project: 
[BasisBreak.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/863274/BasisBreak.zip)


Launch the game, start looking around. Shortly, the camera will break and Godot will log errors on every frame.
It tends to happen when exceeding 90 degrees from the initial point of view.

data.title: Crash on exit, probably caused by audio
data.body:
Tested on Godot master c37fad650f92845a6f59740fea2fea1b46f56db1
Windows 10 64 bits

Everytime I close the editor or sometimes a game, Godot crashes.
In QtCreator I get this exception:

vector.h, line 113, read access violation
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/24226131/f3630d62-0f64-11e7-850a-3e84b7bf95f7.png)

data.title: Vector3.angle_to produces NaNs
data.body:
Tested on Godot 3.0 (not latest, a few days old)
Windows 10 64 bits

In some cases, Vector3.angle_to produces NaN angles, even if the vectors are normalized.
By narrowing down the issue:

```cpp
real_t Vector3::angle_to(const Vector3 &p_b) const {

	return Math::acos(this->dot(p_b) / Math::sqrt(this->length_squared() * p_b.length_squared()));
}
```

I found it's because the value sent to `Math::acos` is sliiiigtly greater than 1, to the point that when printed in GDScript, the console just says `1`, but x > 1.0 outputs `true`.
I added a workaround function in my project that performs a `clamp`, and it worked perfectly.

Sorry I don't have a small repro project, as this happened to me by doing some specific 3D camera movements in this test project: https://github.com/Zylann/godot_flyer_test
See this line of script where my problem occurred: https://github.com/Zylann/godot_flyer_test/blob/master/flyer.gd#L48
It happened by starting the game, doing small mouse movements, and then I got a few occurrences of NaN.

data.title: Built-in function for converting unit vector to euler angles vector
data.body:
Built in function to convert direction vector to euler angles for Vector3 type.

Example situation:
We have normal vector of some surface or collision point and we want to rotate other object to match that normal direction.

data.title: Implement warped mouse panning for 2D & 3D editors
data.body:
Enabled by default as in Blender, but can be disabled separately for 2D & 3D;
the core functionality is in `Input` so this could be reused or even exposed to scripts in the future.

data.body:
Cherry pick #7510 and #7581 to 2.1 branch.
Fix #7676

data.title: Implement warped mouse panning for 2D & 3D editors (2.1)
data.body:
Enabled by default as in Blender, but can be disabled separately for 2D & 3D; the core functionality is in `Input` so this could be reused or even exposed to scripts in the future.

PR for _master_ is on its way.
